bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, January 25, 1929

div1.p: Carter is returning bibliographic cards to Frost and explains how she has organized quotes and references for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, January 25, 1929
div1.opener:
Book.
Bibliography
Frost, Jack
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
January 25, 1929.
Dear Jack:
div1.p: (1) I have just sent, by registered mail, under separate cover:
(a) Certain retyped bibliographic cards of (iii, i) of Father's MS.

(b)Bound copy of above-mentioned MS for (iii, i) made by Rockefeller
Foundation people in 1927.

(c) -- All of the library cards relating to the latter part of Father's
MS, which I brought back with me last December, in order to facilitate
MSwork on the bibliographic cards which you had suggested my retyping.

Miss Brown hads made duplicates of all these ([unclear]d) library cards for me, so
you may now keep the originals in peace!

(2) most earnestly hope that I have not kept you waiting for this
material for (iii, i). I had intended to send it to you e'er this. One
cause for my keeping it as long as I have was that, from your remarks
concerning Brinton and Maya chronology generally, I felt that I should
do everything possible to make the bibliographic cards dealing with this
subject as little involved as possible. This I have done, in some in-
stances, by making from two to four separate bibliographic cards out of
one previously sent you. If you still have any trouble with them, please
advise me and I will go over to Baltimore at any time you wish, taking with
me such books as are needed for reference or explanation.

(2) Please do not think that I have forgotten your request that
I type verbatim quotations on bibliographic cards rather than refer
thereon to “bound corrected MS.” As things now stand, I have only ad-
hered to this latter practice when the corrected quotations, in the
bound MS. were (a) very long and (b) needed little correction. On every
bibliographic card, referring to such corrected quotations in the bound
MS I have given the date: vol. and pagination of the book from which the quota-
tion is taken.

(2′) In connection with the above (2), I have not corrected
corrected
-2-
all of the bound MS for Section iii, part i (It would have taken too
much time), so please check solely by your bibliographic cards save where ex-
pressly referred to “corrected bound MS.”

(3) I have also not forgotten your suggestion that for the last
two divisions of the MS (Section iii, part i (Continued) and Section iii,
part 2) the bibliographic cards be returned to you in the order in which
the references come in the MS rather than grouped alphabetically. I did
not do this with the cards sent you to-day, as you said I need not bother
with (iii, part i) and I therefor only took such bibliographic cards from
this Section out of your files as I feared might delay you through not
being sufficiently clear. It would have been quite easy for us (you and myself) to have
checked them in their original form had there only been time for us to
have gotten in a few consecutive day's work together. I think, now, how-
ever, that the cards are much clearer and that when once you have finished
the editing of Section iii, part i you will be over the worst of the
work--not only in bulk, but in difficulty. The same is true over here:
while there's still a good deal of typing to be done, I can now send you
you any further material just about as soon as you want it. Speaking
specifically, as well as generally, what a calamity this “flu” epidemic
has been! In the former case (and re the book) if it could only have put itself off for
even a short time, we'd have been “over the top” long since and able to
say our “Laus Deo!”..or at least “Nunc dimittis.”

(4) Has Mrs. Smiley begun the final typing of Sections i and ii,
or are you waiting until the whole MS has been edited?

(5) Re the title of the book (you see I shall end on a note of optimism!)
What of simply: “Yellow Fever.”? This vs. “Early History of Yellow Fever,
or something re “Place of Origin of Yellow Fever.”?

With all manner of good wishes to you and yours, and best love to
“the Susans,”
